claim: If rain had started on lap 30 of the 2003 Austrian Grand Prix, Michael Schumacher would not have achieved his fastest career lap that day.
extra_info: fastest lap refers to min(milliseconds); Alex Yoong refers to the full name of the driver; Full name of the driver refers to drivers.forename and drivers.surname;
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim ('If rain had started on lap 30... would not have achieved...'). It describes a hypothetical scenario that cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. Counterfactual claims are always classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
Looking at this claim carefully before touching the database.

The claim states: "If rain had started on lap 30 of the 2003 Austrian Grand Prix, Michael Schumacher would not have achieved his fastest career lap that day."

This is a classic **counterfactual** claim. It describes a hypothetical scenario — "If rain had started on lap 30..." — and speculates about what would have happened under those imagined conditions. The database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened under different weather conditions.

Per the classification rules:

> **COUNTERFACTUAL**: The claim describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario. Look for language like "If X had happened...", "Had X been done...", "If X were changed...", "Would have...", etc. These imagined scenarios CANNOT be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. ALWAYS classify counterfactual claims as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

This claim clearly uses "If rain had started..." and "would not have achieved..." — both hallmark counterfactual constructions.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim ('If rain had started on lap 30... would not have achieved...'). It describes a hypothetical scenario that cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. Counterfactual claims are always classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO."}
```
